questions.text: Why does Mr. Woodhouse call Mrs. Weston 'poor Miss Taylor'?
questions.correct: because he wishes she had never married
options: because she is practically penniless
because her marriage to Mr. Weston is an unhappy one
because Mr. Woodhouse wished to marry her himself
questions.explanation:
because he wishes she had never married.

	Mr. Woodhouse is a kind but fretful invalid who dislikes change. Thus he isn't a fan of marriage. In calling Weston's happy bride 'poor Miss Taylor,' he is attributing his own feelings to her.

questions.text: Why is Emma a little difficult to like during the first half of the book?
questions.correct: She tries to run other people's lives.
options: She falls in love with an undeserving man.
She hurts Mrs. Weston's feelings.
She isn't a dutiful daughter or a good sister.
questions.explanation:
She tries to run other people's lives.

	By trying to make a match between Harriet and Mr. Elton, Emma almost ruins the younger girl's prospects and exposes her to heartache and ridicule.

questions.text: Which food does Mr. Woodhouse like best?
options: custard
roast pork
wedding cake
questions.explanation:
gruel.

	Gruel, as far as I can tell, is a watery porridge-type substance.

questions.text: Why doesn't Mr. Knightley think Miss Smith is a good companion for Emma?
questions.correct: He doesn't think the young women will do each other any good.
options: He doesn't think Miss Smith is very good-hearted.
He doesn't want Mr. Woodhouse to fall in love with Miss Smith.
He doesn't want Emma to find out that Miss Smith is illegitimate.
questions.explanation:
He doesn't think the young women will do each other any good.

	Mr. Knightley doesn't think Emma will benefit from having an adoring admirer, and he thinks Emma may raise Harriet's expectations too high.

options: Harriet
Augusta
Jane
questions.explanation:
Isabella.

	Isabella Woodhouse Knightley is a kind, but not overly intelligent woman who's anxious about health isssues like her father. There's another Isabella (Thorpe) in Northanger Abbey--but she's a creep.

questions.text: At the picnic on Box Hill, Emma hurts __________ feelings.
questions.explanation:
Miss Bates's & Miss Bates'.

	In so many words, Emma tells Miss Bates that the older woman is a silly chatterbox.

questions.text: Why do Jane and Frank keep their engagement secret?
questions.correct: Frank's aunt, Mrs. Churchill may not approve.
options: Jane's grandmother may not approve.
Frank has no financial prospects.
Frank's father and step-mom may not approve.
questions.explanation:
Frank's aunt, Mrs. Churchill may not approve.

	Frank has been adopted by the wealthy Churchills, his aunt and uncle. The aunt, a troublesome woman, would probably not want Frank to marry penniless Jane.

Robert Martin.

	Harriet goes back to her first love interest, after falling in and out of love with Mr. Elton and Mr. Knightley.

questions.text: What do Emma and Mr. Knightley decide to do about Mr. Woodhouse after they marry?
questions.correct: to live with him at Hartfield
options: to bring him to live at Donwell
to send him to live with the London Knightleys
to send him to live with the Westons
questions.explanation:
to live with him at Hartfield.

	Neither Emma nor Mr. Knightley wishes to disrupt Mr. Woodhouse's life unduly.

questions.text: What finally convinces Mr. Woodhouse that Emma and Mr. Knightley should marry?
options: Mrs. Weston's baby is born safely.
Frank and Jane announce their engagement.
Mrs. John Knightley convinces her father to relent.
questions.explanation:
Mrs. Weston's turkeys are stolen.

	After the news about the Westons' turkeys, Mr. Woodhouse becomes deathly afraid of 'house-breakers.' Mr. Knightley plans to move to Hartfield once he and Emma marry. In order to acquire a live-in protector, Mr. Woodhouse decides he can tolerate their marriage.
